content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a list of daily temperature data `temps` (numbers). Write a function `weather_data_analyzer` that performs statistical analyses on this data (use `Statistics` package). The function should return results in named tuple (construct it with `(; key1=value1,key2=value2)` syntax) containing the `average`, `max`, `min` temperatures, and a `trend` (can be only: `:increasing`, `:decreasing`, or `:stable`). If the list is empty, the function should return a named tuple with all values set to `nothing`.

To accomplish this task, you can use the following Julia code. Make sure to have the `Statistics` package installed and imported.

```julia
using Statistics

function weather_data_analyzer(temps::Vector{Union{Missing, Float64}})
    isempty(temps) && return (; average=nothing, max=nothing, min=nothing, trend=nothing)

    filtered_temps = skipmissing(temps)
    avg = mean(filtered_temps)
    mx = maximum(filtered_temps)
    mn = minimum(filtered_temps)

    trend = if length(filtered_temps) == 1
        :stable
    elseif filtered_temps[1] < filtered_temps[end]
        :increasing
    elseif filtered_temps[1] > filtered_temps[end]
        :decreasing
    else
        :stable
    end

    return (; average=avg, max=mx, min=mn, trend=trend)
end
```

This function accepts a vector of `Union{Missing, Float64}` to handle missing values in the temperature data. The function calculates the required statistics and determines the trend based on the first and last non-missing values. If the input list is empty, the function returns a named tuple with all values set to `nothing`.
